messageBody:
Hmm...depending on how you structure your tests, that
would be very easy.

For the most part, I try to name the test methods
testMethodName (where methodName is the actual method
I'm testing) and the class name of the test is
ClassNameTest.

So...if you wrote a little plug-in for whatever IDE
you are using that looked at the current class and
method (or offered a way to selection it) it would be
easy to jump to the test class and method.

Some tests don't fit quite as easily, but that could
be changed easily. As it stands now, looking for the
test for a particular method within my repository is
fairly easy to do manually. ;)

-Eric

--- Jeremy Thornton <jeremy@...>
wrote:
> Hate getting dragged into what seems to be an
> argument about personal style,
> but as everyone else seems to have had something to
> say I'll feel left out
> if I stay quiet ;-)
>
> Does anyone structure their tests to make them more
> useful as documentation
> ? I would be a lot more convinced of the use of
> tests as a sole documentary
> agent if it were easy to use a tool to automatically
> jump to the appropriate
> test for a method from the source code.
>
> Seems to me that tests tend to evolve quite quickly
> and (maybe it's just me)
> haphazardly. One of the reasons I think that JUnit
> is so useful is that it
> is very light-weight. If its usage was altered to
> structure it more, the
> same problems with syncing with the code would
> happen as with integrated
> (javadoc) comments.
>
> Just my tuppence worth.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
> Sent: 22 February 2002 15:26
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
>
> "Heath, Joseph" wrote:
>
> > > Then I'll leave you with this final thought: If
> we design
> > > software by writing tests first, do the tests
> document the
> > > intention of the software, or its
> implementation?
> > >
> >
> > But this assumes that our tests cover all
> possibilities of use, which can
> > result in large test suites. I am not against this
> (in fact I prefer it),
> > but often a few words of English (or whatever
> language you read) is
> > preferrable (IMHO) to a large test suite.
> > I still have the test suite, however, for
> refactoring and code proof.
> >
>
> If we don't write new code until we have a failing
> test, then the tests
> cover all the methods. I agree that they may not
> test all possible
> parameters. We'll maximize the testing investment
> by testing interesting
> boundary conditions and reasonable ranges for
> parameters. Our code coverage
> will still be very high. And yes, we'll amass test
> suites quickly as our
> tests become more comprehensive over time.
>
> If a few words of English is necessary over and
> above the method signature,
> then by all means add it to the documentation.
>
> >
> > I would still say that that the tests document
> examples of the intention,
> > rather than the intention itself. These examples
> may be a complete set or
> > may not be, often just the critical subset.
> >
>
> Agreed. Examples of intention and intention draw
> closer together the more
> we use test-first design. Nevertheless, we're
> documenting intention rather
> than implementation.
>
> Good points - thanks!
>
> Mike
